item.description:
I've been wanting to try and hit some of the other, non-AMC 4,000+ foot prominences and features in the Northern Presis for a while. This will not be your traditional peakbagging climb.  

Instead, we will ascend Adams to John Quincy Adams (a sub-summit of Adams) and then make our way over to Madison, taking a non-traditional route with some interesting features along the way.  PLUS - IT IS HIGHLY LIKELY THAT THE LEAVES WILL BE STARTING TO CHANGE THIS WEEKEND!  We were up Adams this past weekend and things were just starting to turn in the Presis.

Without having done this hike, I can't tell precisely how long it will take - I estimate this as a 9 hour hike without stops, based on book time.  Madison is one of the high peaks in the Whites and on the list of NH/White Mountain 48 4,000 footers.

------------------------- 

We'll ascend to the summit of John Quincy Adams by taking the Ampibrach to the upper part of the King Ravine Trail.  Features on King Ravine include Mossy Falls, "the subway" and ice caves.  The trail will end just below the summit of John Quincy Adams, which we will scramble up and then down.  Then we will summit Madison, and descend taking the Watson Trail to the Brookside Trail.  The descent will feature Bruin Rock and several falls.


Be prepared for cool, cold and potentially poor weather conditions. DO NOT WEAR COTTON OR DENIM. If you have questions about how to prepare or how to dress, ask them in advance.  Come prepared to stay dry!!

Answers to FAQs

  • This IS NOT a traverse, so we will NOT need to carpool to another location.
  • We will meet in the Appalachia Parking Lot on Route 2 
  • Sunset will be at  about 6:50pm.
  • This hike will be VERY EXPOSED.  Come prepared for sun, rain and cold conditions.
  • We will not pass any RMC Huts on this climb.  We WILL pass the Madison Spring Hut but it will be CLOSED.
  • Bring enough water.  While there ARE sources on this trail, they are non-potable so your water will have to be treated.
  • Headlamps are required.  I do not plan to come out in the dark, but this is a long hike and one of the tougher mountains, so I want hikers to be prepared.  Always be prepared to come out in the dark if necessary.
  • We will START AND FINISH TOGETHER. If you cannot hold your speed down to match that of the group (if necessary), this is not the hike for you.   I require participants to wait at trail junctions, major water crossings and summits so that the group can exchange information and reset their pace.
  • I am NOT a speedy hiker, but I do keep a steady pace.  I'm doing about book time these days.
  • If the conditions are prohibitive, I have no qualms about turning around. The mountain will be there another day.  I would like you to be around for another day too.
  • My hikes area always dog friendly, but please know the limits and abilities of your dog & bring plenty of water for the summer heat.  The Northern Presis can be very hard on a dog's feet.  I may have one of my dogs with me for this climb.
  • I will watch the weather carefully and post weather updates during the week leading up to the hike. I rely on NOAA and MWObs for my forecasts.
  • I will provide attendees with my cell phone number in advance of the hike.

 

Most of the payoff comes in the form of great views & enjoying the outdoors.  If the weather looks like it will be miserable, I will reschedule, possibly to Sunday if it looks clearer.  Please plan accordingly.

RSVP Questions are NOT optional - If you do not provide me with a phone number to try and contact you on the morning of the hike (if necessary), we will NOT wait for you at the trailhead.

 

Book time is hard to estimate for this one.  Book time as listed below does not take into account the ascent of John Quincy Adams or stopping at each of the mentioned features.   Plan on it taking about AT LEAST this long & possibly a little more since we intend to spend some time at the true summit.  Last week we did a similar ascent of 4 summits on Adams and still made 1 hour under book time, even with several stops.

 

"Plagerized" Trail Descriptions  from the AMC Guide will follow shortly

Ampibrach Trail to King Ravine Trail

2.6 miles

2 hours 5 minutes

 

King Ravine to base of John Quincy Adams

2.4 miles

2 hours and 5 min

 

Gulfside Trail from King Ravine to Summit of Mt. Madison

Roughly .8 miles and 50 minutes


Watson Path from the summit of Mt. Madison to the Brookside Trail

1.5 miles

1 hours and 30 minutes

 

Brookside Trail to (Lower) Valley Way

1.7 miles
 1 hour 30 minutes

 

Lower Valley Way to the Appalachia Parking Lot

.9 miles

45 minutes


Totals  
--------  
 9.9 miles  
8 hours, 45 minutes


DISCLAIMER (SHAMELESSLY PLAGERIZED FROM ANOTHER MEETUP HIKER): MY ROLE AS ORGANIZER IN THIS HIKE IS SOCIAL. I AM NOT TRAINED TO BE A GUIDE, NOR HAVE I RECEIVED TRAINING OR INSTRUCTION IN HIKING SAFETY. WHILE I TRY TO HEAD OFF SOME OF THE PROBLEMS I HAVE SEEN (OR EXPERIENCED OR EVEN CAUSED) IN THE PAST, MY UNDERSTANDING IS THAT YOU WILL TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR YOUR OWN SAFETY. IF MY DISAPPEARANCE DURING THIS TRIP WOULD CAUSE YOU MORE THAN ANNOYANCE AND INCONVENIENCE, THIS IS NOT THE TRIP FOR YOU. THERE ARE ALWAYS RISKS IN HIKING IN THE MOUNTAINS. IF YOU ARE NOT CONFIDENT THAT YOU UNDERSTAND THE RISKS, PLEASE DO NOT SIGN UP (or change your RSVP to no). WHILE I HAVE CLIMBED THIS PEAK BEFORE, I HAVE DONE ALL MY RESEARCH VIA GUIDEBOOKS, INTERNET AND ADVICE FROM OTHER HIKERS, SO IT IS POSSIBLE THAT SOME INFORMATION IS NOT ACCURATE. I AM PERFECTLY CAPABLE OF MAKING STUPID OR MINDLESS MISTAKES, SO PLEASE DO YOUR OWN RESEARCH AND COME PREPARED WITH APPROPRIATE KNOWLEDGE, EQUIPMENT AND JUDGMENT.
